IX.iii.1.J.4.g
.
How Net Worth Decreases
Net worth can decrease in the following ways:
assets can decrease in value, or
annual income can decrease.
Exception
:  A transfer of assets such as a purchase of an annuity or similar financial instrument does not decrease assets.
Notes
:
The IVAP decreases due to a decrease in income or an increase in prospective medical expenses.
The Veteran, surviving spouse, child, or someone acting on their behalf, may decrease assets by spending them on products or services for which fair market value is received.  The expenses must be those of the Veteran, surviving spouse, or child, or a relative of the Veteran, surviving spouse, or child.  The relative must be a member or constructive member of the Veteran’s, surviving spouse’s, or child’s household.
Reduction in stock portfolios, financial investments, or personal property value results in a corresponding decrease in net worth.
If benefits are denied based on excessive net worth, the claimant is responsible for submitting evidence regarding the change in their net worth to VA.
References
:  For more information on
how net worth decreases, see
38 CFR 3.274(f)
personal property for net worth purposes, see
M21-1, Part IX, Subpart iii, 1.J.1.e
and
f
, and
payment of benefits based on the reconsideration of net worth, see
M21-1, Part IX, Subpart iii, 1.J.1.s
.
